cell.color:
The Extinct Research Lab is the zoo building where you start your search for fossil bones that you piece together to recreate exciting extinct animals! The first step in your journey is finding these fossils. All the information you need can be found by looking up
Fossil Finding
in your Zoopedia.
Once you've found enough pieces, drop into the Extinct Animals Lab and get to work! This entry on
Fossil Building
can help you through the process.
Once you unlock an animal by building its fossil, you can play the Extinct Research Lab's
animal creation
minigame. To start, select the Create Animals tab on the Extinct Research Lab's info panel. Then, select the animal you want to create from the list of fossils built. Then you are transported into the lab's animal creation room, where you must match the pattern of events on the computer screen as the scan line crosses over them. If you do a great job, you get a super version of the animal you selected. These are the happiest, healthiest, and strongest animals, and guests enjoy them most. Do an okay job and you get a regular version of the extinct animal selected. Fail and you might get an animal no one's ever seen before!
Now you know how to find, build, and create amazing extinct animals for your zoo!
Sometimes, one of your animals might catch a disease. Don't worry! The Extinct Research Lab can handle that, too! Go to the
Disease Curing
topic in your Zoopedia to learn more about identifying, researching, and curing diseases in your zoo.

The Cave Painting Hall is more like a cave than a building. Inside, examples of prehistoric cave drawings cover the walls. Seeing how prehistoric man depicted animals in the wild intrigues and educates your guests.

The stage is where
Entertainer
staff perform shows. They don't need a stage to be entertaining, but it really shows off their cool tricks!

The Extinct Education Center is where guests learn about extinct animals firsthand.
Guests build life-size skeletons of extinct animals in the Extinct Education Center. First, they find the animals' bones in the
Play Dig Pit
. Then they bring them to the Extinct Education Center, where they can see each animal's skeleton take shape. Try building an entire skeleton!
The Extinct Education Center is also a place where zoo educators and paleontologists teach guests about extinct animals and fossils. It's a lot like the
animal educator podium.

At the Play Dig Pit, guests get their hands dirty digging for the bones of extinct animals. But guests don't always find fossils ... sometimes they uncover a surprise! But when they do find fossilized bones, they take them to the
Extinct Education Center
to build a skeleton of an extinct animal.
At the Size Comparison Mural, guests see just how huge some extinct animals were by comparing how humans measure up today. This clever mural educates and entertains guests at the same time.

The extinct-themed gift cart is where guests purchase souvenirs to remember their happy day with your extinct animals.
Place the cart in a high-traffic area so guests don't forget to get a gift before leaving your zoo!

The Dino Capture Team bunker is a secret underground building where your
Dino Capture Team
works. If you want to have dinosaurs in your zoo, you'd better have a Dino Capture Team bunker. Dinosaurs can sometimes get unruly and start rampaging around your zoo. When they do, call the
Dino Capture Team
to put your zoo back in order.
Your guests won't know you have a secret team of dino wranglers ready to pounce when needed. The Dino Capture Team bunker hides under a statue of two dinosaurs playing. When activated, the bunker rises from the ground, and your zoo's
Dino Capture Team
springs into action.

Kids love climbing up the Brachiosaurus Slide to get a bird's-eye view of your zoo before they zip down to the bottom of this spiral-thrill ride!
The slide is just about the size of a real Brachiosaurus. Can you imagine having one of these beasts roaming in your zoo? You couldn't keep them enclosed!

These areas indicate where you should dig if you want to find interesting things underground. They are placed automatically when you uncover a potential fossil site in the
Fossil Finding
minigame (see
Extinct Research Lab
for more).
Your paleontologists also roam your zoo flagging these sites for you, so you can dig them up when you have a break in your zookeeper duties.
